title: Paul's Mission in Thessalonica and Athens
shortSummary: Acts 17 recounts Paul's missionary journey through Thessalonica, Berea, and Athens, highlighting his bold preaching of Christ's resurrection and the gospel. The chapter illustrates the varied responses to the gospel, from acceptance and belief to opposition and mockery, culminating in Paul's reasoned defense of the Christian faith before the Areopagus in Athens.
timeline: c. AD 50 - Paul's Second Missionary Journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and primary preacher of the gospel in this chapter, engaging with Jews and Gentiles to proclaim Jesus as the risen Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Silas
keyCharacters.description: Paul's companion and fellow missionary who travels with him, supporting the ministry and helping establish new believers.

keyCharacters.name: Timotheus (Timothy)
keyCharacters.description: A young disciple who remains in Berea with Silas while Paul is sent to Athens, assisting in the ministry.

keyCharacters.name: Jason
keyCharacters.description: A believer in Thessalonica who hosts Paul and Silas; he faces persecution from unbelieving Jews.

keyCharacters.name: Dionysius the Areopagite
keyCharacters.description: A member of the Athenian council who becomes a believer after hearing Paul's message at the Areopagus.

definitions.definition: A Jewish place of worship and teaching where Paul often began his ministry by reasoning from the Scriptures.
A prominent Athenian council and court located on Mars' Hill, where philosophical and religious matters were discussed.
Followers of Epicurus, a philosophical school that taught pleasure as the highest good and often rejected divine providence.
Philosophers who emphasized reason, self-control, and living in accordance with nature, often skeptical of traditional gods.
To turn away from sin and return to God with a changed heart and mind, a central call in Paul's preaching.

outline.heading: Paul's Ministry in Thessalonica
outline.description: Paul and Silas preach in the Jewish synagogue, explaining from the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ who suffered and rose again. Some believe, but opposition arises from unbelieving Jews who incite a riot and accuse Paul and his companions of subverting the city.

outline.heading: The Berean Response
outline.description: Paul and Silas flee to Berea where the Jews receive the message with eagerness and examine the Scriptures daily. Many believe, but opposition from Thessalonica's Jews follows, forcing Paul to depart for Athens while Silas and Timothy remain.

outline.heading: Paul's Witness in Athens
outline.description: In Athens, Paul is distressed by the city's idolatry and engages both Jews and philosophers in daily discussions, attracting the attention of Epicurean and Stoic philosophers.

outline.heading: Paul's Sermon at the Areopagus
outline.description: Paul addresses the Athenians, acknowledging their religiosity but proclaiming the one true God who created all and calls all to repentance. He declares the resurrection of Jesus as the basis for judgment and eternal hope.

outline.heading: Responses to the Gospel in Athens
outline.description: Some mock the message of resurrection, others express interest, and a few, including Dionysius and Damaris, believe and join Paul, demonstrating the varied human responses to the gospel.

application: Be diligent in studying and verifying Scripture as the Bereans did, ensuring your faith is grounded in God's Word.
Boldly proclaim the gospel in diverse settings, trusting God to work through your witness even amid opposition.
Recognize the importance of repentance and turning from sin as a foundational step in following Christ.
Engage thoughtfully and respectfully with those of different beliefs, using reason and Scripture to explain the hope within you.

keyVerses.text: Opening and alleging, that Christ must needs have suffered, and risen again from the dead; and that this Jesus, whom I preach unto you, is Christ.
keyVerses.significance: This verse summarizes the core of Paul's gospel message: the necessity of Christ's suffering and resurrection as fulfillment of Scripture.

keyVerses.text: These were more noble than those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the scriptures daily, whether those things were so.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the exemplary attitude of the Bereans in receiving and verifying the gospel, serving as a model for all believers.

keyVerses.text: God that made the world and all things therein, seeing that he is Lord of heaven and earth, dwelleth not in temples made with hands; Neither is worshipped with men's hands, as though he needed any thing, seeing he giveth to all life, and breath, and all things;
keyVerses.significance: Paul emphasizes God's sovereignty and self-sufficiency, correcting the Athenians' idolatrous beliefs.

keyVerses.text: And the times of this ignorance God winked at; but now commandeth all men every where to repent: Because he hath appointed a day, in the which he will judge the world in righteousness by that man whom he hath ordained; whereof he hath given assurance unto all men, in that he hath raised him from the dead.
keyVerses.significance: This passage calls for repentance and affirms the resurrection of Christ as the guarantee of future judgment and hope.
